> Curious. I'm guessing that you haven't set the environment variables
> ANT_HOME, JAVA_HOME, etc. In Windows, this is done using the System
> Properties | Advanced | Environment Variables dialog (I think - it's
> been a while). Or you could just set them for an instance of the
> command interpreter using set JAVA_HOME=some\path
> Then you can reference them in an ant build.xml  file using <property
> environment="someprefix" /> and then have properties like
> ${someprefix.HTTPUNIT_HOME} - I think that this might be a more usual
> way of referencing them.

I initially started with Windows system variables per: Matt Raible's Wiki
site, but following other advice, I cleaned them out to do everything in
ANT.  I think the intent is to make the project with its build.xml more
portable?  I have found it necessary to define some system variables
before using ANT:

set ANT_HOME=D:\JAVADevEnv\Tools\apache-ant-1.6.2

set Path=C:\WINNT\system32;C:\WINNT;C:\WINNT\System32\Wbem;D:\JAVADevEnv\SDKs\j2sdk-1_4_2_04-windows-i586\lib;%ANT_HOME%\bin


There is a challenge, for a greenhorn, working out an organized approach
by soliciting advice from multiple experts.  That is life!

I believe I understand your suggestion:
  Define the system variables as I had previously, then using them, define
project variables in the ANT build.xml   <property ...

I learn something faster once I understand the why.  I guess that aids
extrapolation beyond specific examples.

---
                Clark Anderson
